SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: As used in paragraph 2, what does the phrase “fading into the background” mean?

A.Choice: disappearing from view

B.Choice: losing its importance in people's minds

C.Choice: moving farther and farther from the city

D.Choice: remaining important only to those who value nature

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which claim from the article is least supported?

A.Choice: “New York didn't seem to need the river anymore, except as a sewer. And that's what it became.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Industry on the river had made some New Yorkers filthy rich.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “But it had just made the river filthy.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “But now there were other dreamers in the valley, with their own dreams of wealth.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: What is the role of paragraph 7 in the organization of the article?

A.Choice: It compares the two groups of dreamers.

B.Choice: It concludes the part of the article about industry.

C.Choice: It introduces the part of the article about activists.

D.Choice: It transitions to the part of the article where change occurs.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does “unblemished” mean as used in paragraph 11?

A.Choice: unaware

B.Choice: unknown

C.Choice: unharmed

D.Choice: unstable

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: How does the idea expressed in paragraph 15 relate to the article?

A.Choice: There are two main ways that the river can be fixed.

B.Choice: The river is able to move in two different directions.

C.Choice: People who benefit from the river must also protect it.

D.Choice: Opposing groups can each get what they want from the river.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence is most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: One company colored the river red and yellow with excess car paint.

B.Choice: The Hudson River became polluted in the effort to gain wealth.

C.Choice: The Mahicans have a saying about taking care of the river.

D.Choice: The author has dreamed of returning to the Hudson River for fifty years.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: Which quotation best expresses the author's point of view in the article?

A.Choice: “In less than 300 years it had grown from a tiny Dutch outpost in the wilderness to the business capital of the world.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “In 1963, Con Edison, New York City's power company, proposed a plan for constructing the largest hydroelectric pumping station ever built.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “More and more people joined the movement as they realized how much difference each of us can make.” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “It's now my turn to help in keeping the river of dreams flowing, for all those dreamers yet to come.” (paragraph 17)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: In paragraph 1, what does the phrase “clattering nerve center of the restaurant” suggest?

A.Choice: messiness, chaos

B.Choice: energy, core

C.Choice: tension, anxiety

D.Choice: greatness, stability

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which quotation best expresses a central idea of the story?

A.Choice: “I started experimenting with being a vegetarian when I turned fourteen ...” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “... I decided early on that this is the work I want to do ...” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “It hardly seems fair that I have to walk away from all of that ...” (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: “... just in case I ever want to do anything else with my life.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 9.
:box:She's the queen of all reasons people can do anything they want in life.
What does this sentence suggest about Julia Child?

A.Choice: Her famous kitchen became part of a cooking museum.

B.Choice: She was successful in a career that interested her.

C.Choice: She always remained calm in the kitchen.

D.Choice: Her cooking style created unique flavor combinations.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: In paragraph 11, what does the one-word statement “Somehow” reveal?

A.Choice: It illustrates the narrator's enthusiasm about her future plans.

B.Choice: It shows the narrator has some questions about whether she will succeed or not.

C.Choice: It shows the narrator does not have every detail of her future plans figured out just yet.

D.Choice: It demonstrates the narrator's lack of knowledge about how difficult her goals are to achieve.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What does the statement “I know I'm going to have to pay my dues” (paragraph 11) show about the narrator's attitude toward her plans?

A.Choice: She thinks the price of fame might be too high.

B.Choice: She realizes success depends on more than setting a goal.

C.Choice: She is highly motivated by the idea of becoming famous.

D.Choice: She thinks becoming a celebrity chef requires only money.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: When the narrator's mother makes her do homework, the narrator rolls her eyes.

B.Choice: When the narrator's mother wanted to invest in a restaurant, Pia wanted to buy the old bank building.

C.Choice: The narrator admires celebrity chefs.

D.Choice: The narrator lives in California.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: The author develops the narrator's point of view mainly through the use of

A.Choice: internal monologue

B.Choice: conflict between characters

C.Choice: limited dialogue

D.Choice: flashback

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: As it relates to the information in the article, what does “With a Few Flat Tires Along the Way” in the title suggest?

A.Choice: Women rode bicycles along rough and unpaved roads.

B.Choice: Women encountered resistance to their efforts.

C.Choice: Women had a difficult time learning to ride bicycles.

D.Choice: Women were unused to dealing with mechanical issues.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 2.

:box:“At sixteen years of age, I was enwrapped in the long skirts that impeded every footstep,” remembered Frances Willard, who in 1895 wrote a best-selling account of how she learned to ride a bicycle at age 53.
Which word from the sentence best helps the reader understand the meaning of “impeded”?

A.Choice: enwrapped

B.Choice: every

C.Choice: footstep

D.Choice: remembered

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3.
:box:But the bicycle changed that.
How does the sentence develop an idea?

A.Choice: It marks a transition.

B.Choice: It introduces an example.

C.Choice: It refines a previous statement.

D.Choice: It provides evidence for a claim.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: What do the details in paragraph 3 reveal about the author's point of view?

A.Choice: The author thinks that clothing restrictions were less of a burden than the necessity of hard work.

B.Choice: The author thinks that all women were treated unfairly regardless of economic status.

C.Choice: The author thinks that poor women had more freedom of dress even though they had to work hard.

D.Choice: The author thinks that the contrast between two classes of women had an effect on their advancement.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: What idea about women riding bicycles is emphasized in paragraphs 6 and 7?

A.Choice: Riding bicycles offered more than just freedom of movement.

B.Choice: Riding bicycles was a simple way to participate in a political movement.

C.Choice: Riding bicycles changed women's fashion.

D.Choice: Riding bicycles was a popular subject in magazines.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: A distinction the author makes between Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Frances Willard is that only

A.Choice: Stanton wrote in favor of women riding bicycles

B.Choice: Willard was actually known to ride a bicycle

C.Choice: Stanton was actually criticized for riding a bicycle

D.Choice: Willard was a true spokeswoman for the bicycle

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which quotation best expresses the central idea of the article?

A.Choice: “Young girls could play outside, but when they matured, their freedom of movement was greatly restricted.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Suddenly, women were leaving their homes to cycle and socialize on country roads and city streets.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Thanks to the wheel, women were starting to be seen and heard in public life.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “It was not a stretch for some cyclists to see the possibility of a larger role for women in the world.” (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: In “So Much Happiness,” what does the comparison in lines 1 through 8 show about happiness? Use two details from the poem to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: In “So Much Happiness,” what do lines 15 through 19 say about how happiness affects the speaker? Use two details from the poem to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: What is a theme of “So Much Happiness?” Use two details from the poem to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Gadgets: Built To Not Last,” what does the phrase “throwaway culture” in paragraph 3 suggest about our society? Use two details from the excerpt to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: What is the role of paragraph 7 in “[Excerpt from] Gadgets: Built To Not Last”? Use two details from the excerpt to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How do paragraphs 1 through 4 develop a central idea in “Don't Fix Your Fridge, Just Buy a New One”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: Why does the author of “Don't Fix Your Fridge, Just Buy a New One” discuss many different types of machines? Use two details from the article to support your response.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: The authors of “[Excerpt from] Gadgets: Built To Not Last” and “Don't Fix Your Fridge, Just Buy a New One” give advice to consumers. What advice does each author give? How does each author use evidence to convince the reader to follow his advice? Which author is the most convincing? Use details from both the excerpt and the article to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• identify the advice each author gives consumers
• explain how each author uses evidence to convince the reader to follow his advice
• evaluate which author is more convincing
• use details from both the excerpt and the article to support your response
